examples.en: I put water in a bottle every day.
examples.ja: 毎日ボトルに水を入れる。

examples.en: Did you put avocado in the sandwich?
examples.ja: サンドイッチにアボカド入れた？

examples.en: Please let me join the volunteer meeting.
examples.ja: ボランティアの会に入れて下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 入 means "enter," but this word does not mean "to enter" (which you already learned as 入る). Still, the meaning of 入れる is still related to the kanji's meaning: it means <vocabulary>to insert</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put in</vocabulary>. It's something you do to another object, like inserting a key into a lock, or your hand into a glove.
reading_mnemonic:
When a vocab is a single kanji plus some okurigana (hiragana stuck on the end of kanji) it's almost always going to be the kun'yomi reading. This is one of two kun'yomi readings you'll be learning for the kanji 入. As long as you know that this vocab means <vocabulary>to insert</vocabulary>, you can use that to remember the reading as well. 

Imagine inserting your hand into a hole and an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) flies out, screaming: "<reading>い</reading>!" This is something that happens every time you insert your hand into something: an eagle comes out. You don't know why.

examples.en: Fireworks get set off in August.
examples.ja: 八月に花火が上がる。

examples.en: Let's take the elevator up three floors.
examples.ja: 三フロア上までエレベーターで上がりましょう。

examples.en: My cholesterol has gone up from last year.
examples.ja: 去年よりコレステロールが上がってしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>above</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to go up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rise</vocabulary>.

It's an intransitive verb, so it doesn't take a direct object. For example: Prices go up. Temperatures rise. See? No direct object. You can remember this because stock prices always seems to go up when you see this one <reading>girl</reading> (がる). You don't know how this girl makes stock prices go up, she just does. Think of her as your lucky girl.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you can guess that it uses the kun'yomi reading. You've learned that reading, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher:

You know this word means <vocabulary>to go up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rise</vocabulary>. Imagine just rising into the air, sort of floating up all of a sudden. What would you say? You'd probably scream "<reading>Ah</reading>!" (あ) the moment you started to go up. You know, out of surprise. Going up? Ah!

examples.en: My mood is lower on rainy days.
examples.ja: 雨の日は気分が下がる。

examples.en: Excuse me. Your jeans are hanging down and I can see your panties.
examples.ja: すみません。ジーンズが下がってパンツが見えてますよ。

examples.en: Scores have dropped since last year.
examples.ja: 去年からスコアが下がった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>below</kanji>, and 下がる means <vocabulary>to get lower</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go down</vocabulary>.

It's an intransitive verb, so it doesn't take a direct object. For example: Prices fall. Temperatures come down. See? No direct object. You can remember this because your fever only goes down when a <reading>girl</reading> (がる) takes care of you. It has to be a girl if you want your fever to come down!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to remember the reading of the kanji:

You know it means <vocabulary>to fall</vocabulary> so instead of using a <reading>sa</reading>w (さ) to cut down the tree, you decide to let it come to you. It has to come down all by itself. Picture yourself placing a saw at the foot of a tree then sitting back and waiting for it to drop itself at your knees. (This could actually work, don't you judge my methods!)

examples.en: It's the day to put out the recycling.
examples.ja: リサイクルのゴミを出す日です。

examples.en: Please take out a notebook.
examples.ja: ノートを出して下さい。

examples.en: I handed a hundred yen to the convenience store cashier.
examples.ja: コンビニのレジで百円を出した。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 出る means "to <kanji>exit</kanji>," and this is the transitive version of that. In other words, you're doing the action of causing something else to exit, so this word means <vocabulary>to take out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hand out</vocabulary>. Think of it like this: when you take out your wallet, you're causing it to exit your pocket.
reading_mnemonic:
The part of the word that you have to learn how to read is the だ portion, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

What are you going <vocabulary>to take out</vocabulary> at the cash register when you need to pay for something? Your <reading>da</reading>d's (だ) credit card, obviously! You love <vocabulary>to hand out</vocabulary> your dad's credit card left and right whenever it's time for a shopping spree. Thanks, Daddy!

examples.en: Money breeds fraud.
examples.ja: お金は不正を生む。

examples.en: The owner of this restaurant is the chef who made Italian cuisine popular in Japan.
examples.ja: このレストランのオーナーが、日本のイタリアンの人気を生んだシェフです。

examples.en: Even though it wasn't my husband's, I had no choice but to give birth to the baby.
examples.ja: 主人の子ではなかったが、生むしかなかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "life" so what is the verb form of that? Would it be "to do life"? No, probably not. In this case it is <vocabulary>to give birth</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to produce</vocabulary>.

You'll have to differentiate this one from the word 生まれる as well. Just remember that when you give birth, you're the one who has to actually <reading>mo</reading>ve (む) your body by finding the right position and pushing with every ounce of strength you can muster. In contrast, when you're being born, you can just kind of lie there and enjoy the ride.
reading_mnemonic:
You have to remember the う part of this word to be able to read it. You already learned this reading with 生まれる, but here's a mnemonic for you just in case you forgot: 

Imagine yourself giving birth, but not to a baby. Instead, it's an <reading>u</reading>ni (う) you're delivering. Luckily, uni aren't fully formed with their spikes at birth so it shouldn't be a problem. Ooof! What a relief!

examples.en: A book stand is something to stand books on.
examples.ja: ブックスタンドは本を立てるためのものです。

examples.en: Will you set up a wooden board here?
examples.ja: ここには木のボードを立てますか？

examples.en: You don't need so much strength in your hand to make a pen stand.
examples.ja: ペンを立てるのに、そんなに手の力はいらないですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "stand" and this means <vocabulary>to stand something up</vocabulary>. It also can mean <vocabulary>to make something</vocabulary>, both in a physical sense, like making a sound, and a mental sense, like making a plan. 

Don't confuse this with 立つ. 立てる means that you're standing something up. As in, "I stood up the action figure" or "I will erect the flag." You're doing the action to something else.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned the kun'yomi reading for this kanji with 立つ, so you should be good to go!

examples.en: Do you know who this person is?
examples.ja: この人、だれか分かる？

examples.en: I immediately knew it was an email from a former partner based on the sentence.
examples.ja: 文で元パートナーからのメールだと、すぐに分かった。

examples.en: It was a book I didn't quite understand.
examples.ja: よく分からない本だった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word means <vocabulary>to understand</vocabulary>, which might surprise you if you remember that the kanji 分 means <kanji>part</kanji>. Think of it this way: to understand something you have to break it down into its parts to see how it works.

Watch out, though, because whereas in English you understand something, in Japanese the thing you understand is the grammatical subject (it's doing the action). So, a more literal meaning for this is <vocabulary>to be understandable</vocabulary>. In other words, there's no object, and 分かる is intransitive, meaning it happens on its own. The かる ending is a hint, because verbs with かる as okurigana (kana added to the kanji) are usually intransitive.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Whenever you try <vocabulary>to understand</vocabulary> something, you just start screaming "<reading>WAAAAAAAAAHHHH</reading>" (わ). It helps you focus and concentrate on what you’re trying to understand, to the dismay of everyone around you. WAAAAAAAAAHHHH.

examples.en: Cars stop at this white line.
examples.ja: この白いラインで車が止まる。

examples.en: I couldn't stop on the skating rink.
examples.ja: スケートリンクの上で、止まることができなかった。

examples.en: The bus almost stopped.
examples.ja: バスは、もう少しで止まりそうでした。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>stop</kanji>, so the verb 止まる means <vocabulary>to stop</vocabulary>. 

But this is the intransitive version, so it doesn't take a direct object. A train stops, or you stop at a red light. See? No direct object. You can remember this because you often have to stop when you see a 丸 (まる), a.k.a. a circle. Think about it — red lights, the cancel symbol, and no trespassing signs are all 丸. Even stop signs are… sort of 丸?
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the 止める, so you should be able to read it already!

examples.en: I have two older brothers.
examples.ja: 兄が二人います。

examples.en: My brother is a project manager.
examples.ja: 兄はプロジェクトマネジャーです。

examples.en: I drove my brother's car to Atlanta.
examples.ja: 兄の車でアトランタまで行きました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This implies that it is your older brother, by the way. Not somebody else's.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your <vocabulary>older brother</vocabulary> is different from everyone else's. He has odd powers... some would say powers of the force. Do you know what his name is? It's <reading>Ani</reading> (あに), short for Anikin... wait a sec, does that sound familiar?

examples.en: Make this character bold, please.
examples.ja: この字は太字にしてください。

examples.en: Is this a bold point pen?
examples.ja: これは太字のペンですか？

examples.en: Sign with a bold pen.
examples.ja: 太字ペンでサインして下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: What do you think a <kanji>fat</kanji> <kanji>letter</kanji> is? If I were to guess, I'd say a <vocabulary>bold letter</vocabulary>. You know, like <vocabulary>bold text</vocabulary> on a screen.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is a bit odd. It combines the kun'yomi ふと from 太 with the on'yomi じ from 字. You learned both these readings with the kanji, so you should be OK here. You'll just have to remember it's a weird mix of kun'yomi and on'yomi. It kind of makes this word stand out… as if it were written in bold letters.

examples.en: The volcano is visible from here.
examples.ja: ここから火山が見える。

examples.en: Can you see the villager over there?
examples.ja: あそこの村人が見えますか？

examples.en: I'm really curious about how I seem to others.
examples.ja: 自分が他人からどう見えるのかがすごく気になる。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>see</kanji>, and 見える is <vocabulary>to be visible</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be in sight</vocabulary>, though it's often more naturally translated into English as <vocabulary>can see</vocabulary>. It's used when you don't actively intend to see something, it just happens.

This verb can also mean <vocabulary>to seem</vocabulary>, when talking about how you perceive something you can see.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). So as long as you know that you should be able to read this word as well.

examples.en: This carpet is made of cow hide.
examples.ja: このカーペットは、牛の皮です。

examples.en: There are gyoza wrappers and beef.
examples.ja: ギョーザの皮と牛肉がある。

examples.en: Melon rind is not the easiest to peel with a peeler.
examples.ja: メロンの皮はピーラーでは中々むけませんね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

皮 refers to <vocabulary>skin</vocabulary> as something separate from the body. You can use 皮 for when your skin starts to peel off with sunburn, or for animal skin when it is being stripped off or turned into a <vocabulary>hide</vocabulary>. You can also use 皮 to describe the outer layer of fruits and vegetables, like apple skins or banana <vocabulary>peel</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

As a human (we think), you have a lot of <vocabulary>skin</vocabulary>. But sometimes a normal shower isn't enough to wash all that skin. What do you do when you can't fit all your skin in the shower or the tub? You get your skin cleaned at the <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>wa</reading>sh, of course!

examples.en: Please shuffle the cards well.
examples.ja: カードをよく交ぜて下さい。

examples.en: The class was a mix of boys and girls.
examples.ja: 男の子と女の子を交ぜたクラスでした。

examples.en: I joined a women's soccer team with a mix of Japanese, French, and British players.
examples.ja: 日本人、フランス人、イギリス人を交ぜた女子サッカーチームに入った。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>mix</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to mix something</vocabulary>. 

It’s transitive, so you’re doing the mixing. With this word, the things you’ve mixed are still distinguishable from each other. Two types of fish in your aquarium, books of different genres on your shelf — that kind of thing.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Who always said not to mix your white and red socks in the laundry? That would be your <reading>Ma</reading> (ま).

examples.en: I'm meeting my mother in the United States.
examples.ja: アメリカで母に会う。

examples.en: I usually meet my older brother once a month.
examples.ja: 兄とは大体、月に一回会います。

examples.en: Have you ever met Koichi from Tofugu in-person?
examples.ja: トーフグのコウイチに生で会ったことある？

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>meet</kanji> so the verb form of that is <vocabulary>to meet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to encounter</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the あ part but let's include the う as well for this one. Who do you want <vocabulary>to meet</vocabulary> more than anyone? Think about it. Then, imagine meeting them. The first thing they do is grab your arm and pinch it. You yell out "<reading>OW</reading>!" (あう) and they laugh and run away.

examples.en: Light comes in through the curtain.
examples.ja: カーテンから光が入る。

examples.en: The light from the sunrise is dazzling.
examples.ja: 日の出の光がまぶしい。

examples.en: Did you see that light last night? It was probably a UFO.
examples.ja: 夕べの光、見た？きっとUFOだったね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Just like its kanji, this word also means <vocabulary>light</vocabulary>. In some cases, it can also refer to a <vocabulary>flash</vocabulary> of light.

This is the more general word for light compared to 明かり, which is why it's often used for sunlight as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

If you could shine <vocabulary>light</vocabulary> on just one thing in the world, it'd be <reading>hickory</reading> (ひかり) smoked bacon, of course! Why hickory? Because no other wood adds that perfect balance of sweet, smoky depth. Not applewood. Not maple. Only the hickory smoked kind deserves the spotlight!

examples.en: The moonlight was very beautiful last night.
examples.ja: 夕べは、月光がとてもきれいでした。

examples.en: White moonlight enters through the curtains.
examples.ja: 白い月光がカーテンから入ってくる。

examples.en: In the moonlight, there was a princess of the moon.
examples.ja: 月光の中に、月の王女がいた。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>moon</kanji> <kanji>light</kanji> is exactly what it sounds like: it's <vocabulary>moonlight</vocabulary>! This word can also refer to a <vocabulary>moonbeam</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, and the reading here changes from げつ to げっ, here's a mnemonic to help you remember how to read this one:

Legend has it that the <vocabulary>moonlight</vocabulary> brings out a creature known as the <reading>Geck光</reading> (げっこう), an elusive species of gecko that shines in the moonlight. You've spent your whole life searching for this gecko. Now imagine spending yet another lonely night crawling around in the moonlit wilderness. Everyone thinks you're crazy, but you know you'll find that Geck光 someday!

examples.en: This apartment gets good sunlight.
examples.ja: このアパートは日光がよく入る。

examples.en: It's not good to expose your body to the sunlight too much.
examples.ja: 日光に体が当たりすぎるのも、よくないよ。

examples.en: There is little sunlight coming from the north.
examples.ja: 北からは日光があまり入らないです。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>sun</kanji> <kanji>light</kanji>. What kind of light would this be? Obviously <vocabulary>sunlight</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since the にち reading of 日 becomes にっ here, we've made a mnemonic for you to remember this reading:

The best place for <vocabulary>sunlight</vocabulary> in Japan is <reading>Nikkō</reading> (にっこう). It's one of Japan's most beautiful national parks, and the perfect spot to catch some rays!

examples.en: These two are the same.
examples.ja: この二つは同じです。

examples.en: I see the same person on the train every day.
examples.ja: 毎日、車内で同じ人に会います。

examples.en: I hope I can be in the same class as Mami-chan.
examples.ja: マミちゃんと同じクラスになれますように。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word is the kanji <kanji>same</kanji> with hiragana attached, and it also means <vocabulary>same</vocabulary>.

It's a bit of an oddball among Japanese adjectives, because you don't need な or い to attach it to a noun. So it's usually considered to be a "special" な-adjective. Have a look at the context sentences to see it in action!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When you think of the word "same" think <vocabulary>same</vocabulary> <reading>owner</reading> (おな). You're looking at a restaurant that has a sign that says, "New owners!" However, when you walk in you see it's the same terrible owner you remember from before. What a liar.

examples.en: The DVD and CD were released on the same day.
examples.ja: DVDとCDが同日にリリースされた。

examples.en: Can you go to Seattle and Portland in the same day?
examples.ja: 同日にシアトルとポートランドに行けますか？

examples.en: Apollo 11 went to the moon on the same day as my father turned thirty.
examples.ja: アポロ１１号が月へ行ったのは、父が三十才になった日と同日だ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji>, which comes out to <vocabulary>same day</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is quite formal. To say <vocabulary>the same day</vocabulary> more casually, just use 同じ日 (おなじひ)!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

On the <vocabulary>same day</vocabulary>, you once ate two entire <reading>dou</reading>ghnuts. <reading>Gee, two</reading> (どうじつ) on the same day? How did that feel?

examples.en: I only watched TV once today.
examples.ja: 今日はテレビを一回だけ見た。

examples.en: This ball is for dogs. How many times do I have to tell you that it's not a ball for a baby?
examples.ja: これは犬用のボール。赤ちゃんのボールじゃないって、何回言ったら分かるの？

examples.en: Your first kiss is an important event you only get to experience once in your life.
examples.ja: ファーストキスは人生で一回しかない大切なものなんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji. This is probably because this word gets attached to numbers usually, which makes it behave more like jukugo. So, you can have １回, ２回, ３回, or even １００回 if you're into that sort of thing.

examples.en: The coin spins on the table.
examples.ja: テーブルの上で、コインが回る。

examples.en: There are two types of sushi. "Sushi that goes around" and "sushi that doesn't go around".
examples.ja: スシには、「回るスシ」と「回らないスシ」二つのタイプがあります。

examples.en: Last year on Valentine's day I went around the class and got chocolates from girls.
examples.ja: 去年のバレンタインはクラス中を回って女子からチョコレートをもらった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>times</kanji>. There's no good verb for the word "times" but you can probably imagine something doing something over and over and over again. What word would represent this? It would be <vocabulary>to revolve</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to go around</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to rotate</vocabulary>.

Bear in mind that this verb is intransitive, so it happens on its own. Something revolves or rotates, all by itself.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have a bag of walnuts that you're bringing to a friend's house but you trip and drop them all on the ground. You shout, "<reading>Mah Wa</reading>lnuts! (まわ)" as they start <vocabulary>to revolve</vocabulary> around you on the ground. Picture your walnuts going around you, getting all dirty.

examples.en: Please say it once more.
examples.ja: もう一回、言ってください。

examples.en: On weekdays, I shower once a day.
examples.ja: 平日は一日に一回シャワーをあびます。

examples.en: Every month, I go to town for ramen at least once.
examples.ja: 毎月、一回はラーメンをたべに町へ出かけます。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>one time</vocabulary>. How many times? Just one.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that 一 is shortened (as it often is) to いっ.

examples.en: I decided to pass this time.
examples.ja: 今回は、やめておきます。

examples.en: I got a gold medal in the Olympics this time.
examples.ja: 今回のオリンピックでは金メダルだった。

examples.en: The topic this time is "robot engineering."
examples.ja: 今回のトピックは「ロボット工学」です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>this time</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The ones who go to that meeting every time are those three.
examples.ja: あのミーティングに行くのは毎回この三人です。

examples.en: I run the Boston Marathon every time.
examples.ja: ボストンマラソンには、毎回出ています。

examples.en: I feel like my score goes down with every test.
examples.ja: 毎回のテストでスコアが下がっていく気がする。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is really just <vocabulary>every time</vocabulary>. Do you get your kanji readings correct 毎回?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are many people in New York.
examples.ja: ニューヨークは人が多い。

examples.en: There are many people who say they're right.
examples.ja: 「自分は正しい」と言う人は多い。

examples.en: This village is the most populated village in Japan.
examples.ja: この村は、日本一人口が多い村です。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>many</kanji>? It is also <vocabulary>many</vocabulary> (or you could say <vocabulary>much</vocabulary>). Speaking of which, there are so many kanji to learn, ammiright?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Think of something that is <vocabulary>many</vocabulary>. Doesn't matter what it is as long as you imagine a ridiculous number of them. Many of them. So many that they start avalanching into you and crushing you. The last thing you yell is "<reading>おお</reading>!!!" as you get smushed.

examples.en: That tree is probably bamboo.
examples.ja: あの木は多分、竹です。

examples.en: August 5th is probably a holiday.
examples.ja: 八月五日は多分休みですよ。

examples.en: My husband is probably going to Singapore.
examples.ja: 主人は多分シンガポールに行きます。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>many</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>s. Look at them all. You have to choose one of the parts. You can't decide which one you want. This one? <vocabulary>Maybe</vocabulary>. How about this one? Hmm, <vocabulary>maybe</vocabulary> that one too.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Apparently you can win a TV.
examples.ja: テレビが当たるらしいよ。

examples.en: See? I was right!
examples.ja: やっぱりそうでしょ？当たってた！

examples.en: Stop it! What if a stone hits someone?
examples.ja: やめろよ！人に石が当たったらどうするんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know this is a verb because it ends with an う sound. The kanji for this word is <kanji>right</kanji> or <kanji>success</kanji>, so what's the verb form of that? Turns out it's a ton of things. But it's mostly for when things go right. As in <vocabulary>to be right</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be on target</vocabulary>. 

当たる is intransitive, so it doesn't take a direct object. Your answer is right, or your shot is on target. See? No direct object.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the あ portion. 

When your guess turns out <vocabulary>to be right</vocabulary>, you can't help but shout, "<reading>Ah</reading>! (あ)" That "Ah" is your victory cry.

examples.en: The word "Jackpot!" caught my eye.
examples.ja: 「当たり！」という文字が目に入った。

examples.en: I won a million yen.
examples.ja: 百万円の当たりが出た。

examples.en: One out of every three people I interviewed was Japanese.
examples.ja: インタビューした三人当たり一人は日本人でした。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>right</kanji>. What happens when you get "a right?" You get <vocabulary>a success</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the あ portion of this word to read it. What is the correct answer that will give you <vocabulary>a success</vocabulary>? It is the first answer, <reading>A</reading> (あ).

examples.en: Do you hold this workshop every month?
examples.ja: このワークショップは毎月ありますか？

examples.en: It is closed on the 5th of every month.
examples.ja: 毎月五日は休みです。

examples.en: The money I spend on convenience store ice cream every month comes to about 30,000 yen.
examples.ja: 毎月コンビニのアイスにかかるお金は三万円くらいです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>moon</kanji> is <vocabulary>every month</vocabulary> (as you know from all the month-related vocab). This can also mean <vocabulary>monthly</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word has the on'yomi reading for 毎 plus the kun'yomi reading for 月. That makes it まいつき.

examples.en: I run every day.
examples.ja: 毎日ランニングをします。

examples.en: I go to work by car every day.
examples.ja: 毎日車で会社に行きます。

examples.en: My daily routine is to go to a convenience store for ice cream.
examples.ja: アイスのためにコンビニに行くのが毎日のルーティーンです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is <vocabulary>daily</vocabulary> (or just <vocabulary>every day</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

<vocabulary>Every day</vocabulary> you watch your favorite program, <reading>My</reading> <reading>Nietzsche</reading> (まいにち). It's a <vocabulary>daily</vocabulary> cartoon about Nietzsche and his life, which you follow religiously. Oh how much you love Nietzsche.

examples.en: I do cherry blossom viewing every year in April.
examples.ja: 毎年四月に花見をします。

examples.en: I put the annual events in the calendar.
examples.ja: 毎年のイベントはカレンダーにかいたよ。

examples.en: How many loaves of bread do I eat every year?
examples.ja: 毎年、何斤のパンをたべるんだろう？

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>every</kanji> and <kanji>year</kanji> to combine into <vocabulary>every year</vocabulary> (<vocabulary>yearly</vocabulary> works as well).
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 毎 is what you'd expect. The reading for 年 is the kun'yomi reading, though. So, use your knowledge of the vocab 年 to help yourself to remember the reading for this word. You'll need to remember that the reading for this word is strange to get it into that brain of yours.

examples.en: This is rice from California.
examples.ja: これはカリフォルニアの米です。

examples.en: Rice costs 500 yen per kilogram.
examples.ja: 米は一キロ当たり五百円です。

examples.en: Rice shortages rarely happen in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本で米が不足することは、あまりない。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 

Note that this word refers to the grains of rice more than something that's a meal. If you're eating rice at a meal you'd call it ごはん. This is like when you're talking about the rice in the fields or rice grains or something like that.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

"Everyone, we have rice! <reading>Come</reading> (こめ) and get it!"

examples.en: This insect has red wings.
examples.ja: この虫には赤い羽がある。

examples.en: These may be our pet emu's feathers.
examples.ja: これはうちのペットのエミューの羽かもしれません。

examples.en: My father spreads his wings and drinks beer on the couch when my mother isn't around.
examples.ja: 父は、母がいないときは羽を広げてソファでビールをのんでいる。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji with nothing attached it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read this.

examples.en: I think of ideas.
examples.ja: アイディアを考える。

examples.en: Let me think a little.
examples.ja: 少し考えさせてください。

examples.en: Let's think about ourselves more.
examples.ja: もっと自分について考えましょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>think</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to think about</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to consider</vocabulary>. 

Note that this isn't the "to think" that is like "I think that he is a power ranger." No, this is more like the actual thinking action. That's why this word is "to think about" or "to consider" rather than plain old "to think" which is 思う.
reading_mnemonic: If you want <vocabulary>to think</vocabulary>, the best way to do so is to do the <reading>conga</reading> (かんが). Imagine yourself doing the conga and thinking away. You're so inspired! The thoughts are flowing as freely as your sweet, slow dance moves.

examples.en: Does this curry have meat in it?
examples.ja: このカレー、肉は入ってますか？

examples.en: Beef from Japan-raised cattle is delicious.
examples.ja: やはり日本生まれの牛の肉は、おいしいです。

examples.en: Meat is very important in my life.
examples.ja: わたしの人生にとって、お肉はとても大切です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Luckily for you, this word uses the on'yomi reading that you learned even though it's a single kanji all on its own. So, you should know it already!

examples.en: Is beef okay?
examples.ja: 牛肉は平気ですか？

examples.en: Dinner last night was beef curry.
examples.ja: 夕べのディナーは牛肉のカレーだった。

examples.en: Do you eat raw beef in Japan?
examples.ja: 日本では生の牛肉をたべますか？

meaning_mnemonic: What do you call <kanji>cow</kanji> <kanji>meat</kanji>? You call it <vocabulary>beef</vocabulary> (what's for dinner?).
reading_mnemonic: Both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

examples.en: My father is an ironic man.
examples.ja: 父は、皮肉な男だ。

examples.en: I didn't know if my teacher's joke was ironic or not.
examples.ja: 先生のジョークは、皮肉なのかどうか、分からなかった。

examples.en: Ironically, Japan's Katakana English is very difficult for my American-born mother.
examples.ja: 皮肉にも、日本のカタカナイングリッシュはアメリカ生まれの母には、とてもむずかしい。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>skin</kanji> on the <kanji>meat</kanji> is kind of like the outer shell. It's not very nice, and people who eat only meat skin tend to use <vocabulary>sarcasm</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>irony</vocabulary>. That being said, Japanese people don't really understand sarcasm. So, maybe that's why "meat skin" means "sarcasm." Is this ironic? Now I'm not even sure.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I was the only man there.
examples.ja: 男は自分だけだった。

examples.en: Did you cut this tree yourself?
examples.ja: この木、自分で切ったの？

examples.en: Please clear your own plates yourself.
examples.ja: 自分のお皿は自分で下げて下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: One’s <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji> is, after everything, still <vocabulary>oneself</vocabulary>. And the part that’s from my self is, well, <vocabulary>myself</vocabulary>. Everyone has their own part of their self. Pretty straightforward.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My goal by the end of the year is to be independent.
examples.ja: 年内のゴールは自立することです。

examples.en: My child's having a hard time becoming independent.
examples.ja: うちの子、中々自立できないんです。

examples.en: I joined a group that supports homeless people becoming independent.
examples.ja: ホームレスの人々の自立をサポートするグループに入った。

meaning_mnemonic:
By your<kanji>self</kanji>, you managed to <kanji>stand</kanji>. Nobody helped you. You stood up on your own, and you really showed your <vocabulary>independence</vocabulary> in the process!

自立 primarily refers to a person's <vocabulary>self-reliance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>autonomy</vocabulary> — their ability to stand on their own, make decisions, and act independently (as opposed to the political independence of a country or something).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This color is cobalt blue.
examples.ja: この色はコバルトブルーです。

examples.en: Today's sunrise was a beautiful orange.
examples.ja: 今日の日の出は、きれいなオレンジ色でした。

examples.en: This poster has a good color balance.
examples.ja: このポスターは色のバランスがいいね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, though, so enjoy.

examples.en: There are various types of people.
examples.ja: 色々なタイプの人がいます。

examples.en: I studied in various classes at university.
examples.ja: 大学では色々なクラスで学びました。

examples.en: I thought about various things, but in the end I think the most important thing in life is money.
examples.ja: 色々考えたんですが、やはり人生で大切なものはお金だとおもいます。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the kanji <kanji>color</kanji> repeated twice (the 々 character just repeats the kanji before it). When you have colors and colors and colors, you have a lot of variety. That's why this word means <vocabulary>various</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this kanji is just the kun'yomi reading twice. Since you've learned the kun'yomi reading already, you should be able to read this word as well. Nothing tricky about it.

examples.en: I want that light blue bag.
examples.ja: あの水色のバッグがほしいんですが。

examples.en: I got sky blue paint by mixing blue and white paint.
examples.ja: 青いペンキと白いペンキをまぜて、水色のペンキができた。

examples.en: Why is the sky light blue today?
examples.ja: どうして今日の空は水色なんだろう？

meaning_mnemonic: You'd think that <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> would have something to do with watercolors, but it doesn't. No, it has to do with the color of water, which, ironically, is <vocabulary>sky blue</vocabulary> in English. <vocabulary>Light blue</vocabulary> works as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word consists of the kun'yomi reading of <kanji>水</kanji> and the kun'yomi reading of <kanji>色</kanji>. For 水 you'll know this reading via your vocab studies. For 色 it just so happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I'm going to Japan in November.
examples.ja: 十一月に、日本に行く。

examples.en: I've got other plans so I probably can't make it to the party next month.
examples.ja: 他の用があるので、来月のパーティには多分行けません。

examples.en: I wouldn’t want to go to the moon if they don’t have Taco Bell there.
examples.ja: タコベルがないなら月には行きたくない。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>go</kanji> so the verb form of this is <vocabulary>to go</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the い portion. To remember い we use the word "eagle." 

You want <vocabulary>to go</vocabulary> somewhere (anywhere!) but you can't. An <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) blocks your path. You try to go forward and it opens its wings and bites at you. You try to go back and it jumps at you. There's nowhere for you to go with this eagle standing there.

examples.en: This bus is bound for Seattle.
examples.ja: このバスはシアトル行きです。

examples.en: Were you able to get some rest on the departing flight?
examples.ja: 行きのフライトでは少し休めましたか？

examples.en: I'm going to go by car and come home by bus.
examples.ja: 行きは車で行って、バスでかえるつもりです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a weird word. Call it exceptional. You'll see this at train stations, especially. You know the kanji means <kanji>go</kanji>. So, something is going somewhere. Now just use the き to help you to remember that this word means <vocabulary>train direction</vocabulary> (aka it tells you which direction a train is going), because this word is the key (き) to you knowing what direction you're going in so you don't get lost. You could also remember this word as "<vocabulary>bound for</vocabulary>" aka "Bound for Tokyo Station."
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is also an exception. It can be いき, but instead we're focusing on the ゆき reading. You have to remember the ゆ portion, so think of it this way: 

Just think about the <vocabulary>train direction</vocabulary> that <reading>you</reading> (ゆ) need to go in. It's all about you. Not your friends or anyone else. You. You are the most important person at this train station.

examples.en: Which way is West?
examples.ja: 西はどっちの方ですか？

examples.en: I was born in western Japan.
examples.ja: 西日本の生まれです。

examples.en: There are many convenience stores and supermarkets west of the company.
examples.ja: 会社の西にはコンビニやスーパーがたくさんあります。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic refresher just in case: 

You go off to the <vocabulary>west</vocabulary>. It's the Wild West, even. There aren't many people out here, making it easy to find a <reading>niche</reading> (にし) for your snake oil business.

examples.en: We've got thousands of errors.
examples.ja: 何千回もエラーが出た。

examples.en: Mami has eaten thousands of bacon strips in her life.
examples.ja: マミは人生で何千ものベーコンをたべてきた。

examples.en: I wonder how many thousand meters more I should go.
examples.ja: この先、何千メートル行けばいいんだろう。

examples.en: How many thousand yen?
examples.ja: 何千円ですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>What</kanji> <kanji>thousand</kanji>? Could be five thousand, two thousand, or ten thousand, since you're asking. Let's generalize. How do you say all of those amounts at the same time? You say "<vocabulary>thousands</vocabulary>."

If this is used in a question, it can also mean <vocabulary>how many thousands</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi なん for 何 and the rendaku'd on'yomi reading for 千 (ぜん) combined together. It's one of those weird words that mixes the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings.

examples.en: What?
examples.ja: 何？

examples.en: What do you want for dinner?
examples.ja: ディナーは何がいい？

examples.en: What flower is this?
examples.ja: これは何の花ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. What? Yeah, that's what.

examples.en: How many people are on your staff?
examples.ja: スタッフは何人ですか？

examples.en: How many people came to that party?
examples.ja: そのパーティーには、何人来ましたか。

examples.en: About how many men have you ever been on a date with?
examples.ja: 今まで大体何人の男の人とデートに行きましたか？

meaning_mnemonic: When you ask <kanji>what</kanji> <kanji>people</kanji> you're not actually asking "what people?" You're asking <vocabulary>how many people</vocabulary>. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that 何, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 何 and the on'yomi reading for 人. Since 何 and 人 both have two readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use:

<vocabulary>How many people</vocabulary> eat <reading>naan</reading> at <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (なんにん)? You've been tasked with counting everybody eating naan for lunch at Nintendo, so you better get started!

examples.en: What month are you born in?
examples.ja: 何月生まれですか？

examples.en: What month will you enroll?
examples.ja: 何月に入学しますか？

examples.en: It doesn't matter what month we go to Hawaii.
examples.ja: ハワイに行くのは何月でもいいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>what</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> - as in: <vocabulary>what month</vocabulary> is it? It's １０月, you fool. Get a job, hippy.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but 何 actually uses the kun'yomi reading here! And since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading:

<vocabulary>What month</vocabulary> gives you <reading>naan</reading> <reading>guts</reading> (なんがつ)? It's the month you eat so much naan that even your guts turn into naan! But <vocabulary>which month</vocabulary> was it again?

examples.en: How many days will you take off from your part-time job?
examples.ja: アルバイト、何日休むんですか。

examples.en: What day's good for you?
examples.ja: 何日がいい？

examples.en: How many days were you stuck in the elevator?
examples.ja: エレベーターから何日出られなかったんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>What</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> equals the fairly obvious translation "<vocabulary>what day</vocabulary>." But, it also means <vocabulary>how many days</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but 何 actually uses the kun'yomi reading here! And since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading:

<vocabulary>How many days</vocabulary> does it take you to bake a <reading>naan</reading> <reading>Nietzsche</reading> (なんにち)? It's not easy to make a Nietzsche entirely out of naan, so I wonder how many days it would take.

examples.en: What year was your husband born?
examples.ja: ご主人は、何年生まれですか？

examples.en: How many years have you been in the United States?
examples.ja: 何年くらいアメリカにいましたか？

examples.en: I haven't seen my brother in years.
examples.ja: 兄にはもう何年も会ってません。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have the kanji <kanji>what</kanji> and <kanji>year</kanji>, as in: "<vocabulary>what year</vocabulary> is it?" 

This also means <vocabulary>how many years</vocabulary> too, depending on the context. As in: "<vocabulary>How many years</vocabulary> did you play soccer?"
reading_mnemonic: The readings are both the readings you learned with the separate kanji, meaning you should know them. How many years have you been studying kanji now? You should be able to read this one.

examples.en: How many times did you go out with your husband last month?
examples.ja: 先月ご主人とは何回出かけましたか？

examples.en: This video is so funny that I have to watch it a bunch of times.
examples.ja: このビデオ、おもしろすぎて何回も見てしまうわ。

examples.en: How many times have you been to Japan?
examples.ja: 日本へは何回来たことがありますか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>What</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji>? This doesn't make any sense. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that 何, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you. So, for this one it's <vocabulary>how many times</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word with a slightly unique reading, where the first kanji uses the kun'yomi reading and the second uses the on'yomi reading. You've seen these readings before, so you should be able to read this alright.

examples.en: There are so many things to learn in life.
examples.ja: 人生は学ぶことが多いです。

examples.en: My brother is a student studying robotic engineering.
examples.ja: 兄はロボット工学を学ぶ学生です。

examples.en: Learning is important, but perhaps what’s more important is how you learn.
examples.ja: 学ぶことは大切だけど、多分もっと大切なのは、どのように学ぶかということ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>study</kanji> or <kanji>learning</kanji>. When you do these things, what ends up happening? You learn. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to learn</vocabulary>. 

There is another word that means "to learn" that is going to be more common, which is 習う. You'll learn this one later on. 学ぶ sounds a little more serious compared to 習う, so keep that in mind when you use it.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the まな part to learn this word's reading. Think about a class you're taking. It's a manners class, and you're there <vocabulary>to learn</vocabulary> <reading>manner</reading>s (まな). Imagine this study of manners and imagine yourself practicing it.

examples.en: My mother is a medical school student.
examples.ja: 母はメディカルスクールの学生です。

examples.en: Some people come to Japan on fraudulent student visas.
examples.ja: 不正な学生ビザを用いて日本に来る人々もいます。

examples.en: Is it true that if you say you're a "student of life" you'll get a student discount?
examples.ja: 「人生の学生です」と言えば、学生のディスカウントがうけられるっていうのは本当なんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: Who has a <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji>? Only one person that I know of, and that's a <vocabulary>student</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My brother is a school year ahead of me.
examples.ja: 兄は一つ上の学年です。

examples.en: Some friends are from the same grade.
examples.ja: 学年が同じの友人もいます。

examples.en: I skipped classes for the whole school year and went to Australia.
examples.ja: 一学年分のクラスをサボって、オーストラリアに行きました。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is kind of like the years you've studied. Where do you study? School. What is a year of study in a school? It's your <vocabulary>school grade</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Congratulations on your enrollment.
examples.ja: 入学おめでとう。

examples.en: My brother is a freshman who just enrolled in school.
examples.ja: 兄は入学したばかりの一年生です。

examples.en: The cost of school admission was about 100,000 yen.
examples.ja: 入学にかかったお金は、大体十万円でした。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>enter</kanji> into a <kanji>study</kanji> (place). When does this happen? It happens when you get accepted into a school, aka <vocabulary>school admission</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>university admission</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>entry into school</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I want to take a robot engineering class.
examples.ja: ロボット工学のクラスに入りたい。

examples.en: After studying engineering, I joined my current company.
examples.ja: 工学を学んでから今の会社に入社しました。

examples.en: Design and engineering are similar depending on the perspective.
examples.ja: デザインと工学は見方によっては近いものです。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone with the <kanji>study</kanji> of <kanji>industry</kanji> is someone who creates things. That would be the study of <vocabulary>engineering</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My father entered college in 1991.
examples.ja: 父は、１９９１年に大学に入った。

examples.en: I studied French literature at university.
examples.ja: 大学ではフランス文学を学びました。

examples.en: Many college students in Japan are younger than twenty five.
examples.ja: 日本の大学は、二十五才より年が下の学生が多いです。

meaning_mnemonic: What's the <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>study</kanji>? If I had to choose, I'd probably say this is <vocabulary>college</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>university</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Your <vocabulary>university</vocabulary> is best known for its <reading>dye</reading> <reading>gawk</reading>ing (だいがく). It's a sport in which you gawk at dye, and your university is the best at it! Other universities might be known for their football or basketball teams, but yours is the best at dye gawking.

examples.en: I want to take a leave of absence.
examples.ja: 休学したいなぁ。

examples.en: During my leave of absence, I stayed in my father's apartment.
examples.ja: 休学中は父のアパートにいました。

examples.en: I want to take a leave of absence and go to France on a working holiday.
examples.ja: 休学してフランスにワーキングホリデーに行きたいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>rest</kanji> from <kanji>school</kanji> you are taking an <vocabulary>absence from school</vocabulary>. This is only for very long absences though, not a day or a week, but months or years. Think about it like taking an extended leave of absence from school.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are many log houses in that forest.
examples.ja: あの林にはログハウスがたくさんあります。

examples.en: I left the forest early as there were a lot of bugs.
examples.ja: 虫がたくさんいたので、林からは早々に出ましたよ。

examples.en: I saw bamboo shoots coming out of the soil in the bamboo forest.
examples.ja: 竹の林の中で、竹の子が土から出るのを見たんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. You've already learned this reading with the kanji, though, so you should be able to read this.

examples.en: The mountain air is so clean.
examples.ja: 山は空気がきれいですね。

examples.en: Some cool air came in from the outside.
examples.ja: 外から、つめたい空気が入ってきた。

examples.en: Please just take the hint.
examples.ja: ちょっとは空気をよんで下さい。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji>... once known as a mystical essence that kept us from flying into space. Now we know this is the <vocabulary>air</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>atmosphere</vocabulary>, though, because that's what a bunch of air between the earth and space is called. ここの空気はいいね！

Figuratively, this can also refer to the <vocabulary>mood</vocabulary> that's in the air or room, but not a specific person's mood!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The sky is big.
examples.ja: 空は広い。

examples.en: The western sky was orange yesterday evening.
examples.ja: 夕べ、西の空はオレンジ色だった。

examples.en: You can't see the moon in the sky because of the rain.
examples.ja: 雨のせいで、空には月が見えません。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

In the sky, you are the ruler. You are known as "The <reading>soarer</reading>!" (そら). Imagine your theme song and make sure it includes "soarer of the sky" or something awesome like that.

examples.en: I gave her a gold necklace.
examples.ja: 金のネックレスをプレゼントしました。

examples.en: Is this real gold?
examples.ja: これは本当の金ですか？

examples.en: Apparently, there are toilets made of gold in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本には金でできたトイレがあるそうだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji you would normally think it uses the kun'yomi reading. Not this word, though. It still uses the on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji. Don't confuse this one with お金, though. That one uses kun'yomi which you know because it has a hiragana attached.

examples.en: That is not a testicle.
examples.ja: それは金玉ではありません。

examples.en: I'm satisfied with my testicles.
examples.ja: 自分の金玉が気に入ってます。

examples.en: Testicles are one of the most important parts of a man's body.
examples.ja: 金玉は男の人の体の中でも大切なパーツの一つです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have some <kanji>gold</kanji> <kanji>ball</kanji>s. What balls are more important than any other balls, at least for a dude? That would be his <vocabulary>testicles</vocabulary>. 

This word came about because tanuki scrotum skin would be used to pound down gold into sheets. Tanuki scrotums are apparently very good at this because they are very strong and very flexible. Strange, yeah? That's why Gold balls = testicles.

As you might have guessed, this word is slang and you'll probably want to avoid using it at the doctor's! It's a comical word that is used in casual situations.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi for 金 and the kun'yomi for 玉. If you know the readings of your kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Wedding rings are more important than money.
examples.ja: ウェディングリングは、お金よりも大切です。

examples.en: Last month, I got a lot of money from gambling.
examples.ja: 先月はギャンブルで多くのお金が入った。

examples.en: There were some problems with the way of managing financials at the head office.
examples.ja: 本社のお金のマネジメントの仕方に不正があった。

meaning_mnemonic: The お is an honorific that makes this word a bit more fancy. When you're talking about money you gotta be fancy, after all. So, you're basically saying "gold" in a nicer way. What was gold back in the day? It was <vocabulary>money</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for 金 is different from the one you learned with the kanji. Makes sense since this is a single kanji with hiragana attached. Here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You've saved up a ton of money. With it you're going to buy something awesome. Then, suddenly someone hits you in the knees with a bat. Now you have to spend all your <vocabulary>money</vocabulary> buying a <reading>cane</reading> (かね). Sucks for you :(

examples.en: It's rainy today.
examples.ja: 今日は雨だ。

examples.en: It rains in Portland for about four months out of the year.
examples.ja: ポートランドは一年の内、大体四ヶ月は雨です。

examples.en: I often stay in my apartment instead of going out when it rains on my day off.
examples.ja: 雨の休日は出かけないでアパートの中にこもることが多いです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, you learned this reading with the kanji.

examples.en: This blue flower is sweet pea.
examples.ja: この青い花はスイートピーです。

examples.en: This orange is still unripe.
examples.ja: このオレンジ、まだ青いですね。

examples.en: Where is the town with blue skies and white beaches?
examples.ja: 青い空と白いビーチのある町はどこですか？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>blue</kanji>? It's still <vocabulary>blue</vocabulary>! It can also mean <vocabulary>unripe</vocabulary>, which might sound confusing, but it comes down to the fact that in Japanese there's some overlap between blue and green. So while in English we think of the "go" traffic light and unripe bananas as "green," in Japanese they're actually called "blue."
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the あお portion to read this word. Think of <vocabulary>blue</vocabulary> things on your body. Those are bruises. Touch them. What would you say? <reading>OW!</reading> (あお).

examples.en: The young man was eighteen years old.
examples.ja: その青年は十八才でした。

examples.en: What a generous young man you are.
examples.ja: あなたは、なんて心の広い青年だ。

examples.en: The young man said he wanted to be a pilot when grows up.
examples.ja: 青年は大人になったらパイロットになりたいと言っていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
Someone who is in their <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>youth</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>young man</vocabulary>. 

青年 refers to <vocabulary>young adult</vocabulary>s, usually in their late teens to early twenties. The word is gender-neutral in legal or official contexts, but in everyday use 青年 usually refers to young men.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. That said, this reading can be easy to confuse with other similar words, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

The <vocabulary>youth</vocabulary> like to play with <reading>sa</reading>bers (せい) and <reading>nen</reading>doroids (ねん). Think about it: as you leave childhood and become a 青年, you want more mature and dangerous hobbies, right? So you move on from plastic swords and soft toys to playing with real sabers and nendoroid action figures. You're such a cool 青年.

examples.en: There's nothing but grass around here.
examples.ja: ここは草ばかりだ。

examples.en: Taking care of grass is quite a pain.
examples.ja: 草の手入れは中々めんどくさいです。

examples.en: Other than grass, cows eat rice and things like that.
examples.ja: 牛は草の他にも米などをたべますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.

examples.en: This is the sound of a Ferrari engine.
examples.ja: これはフェラーリのエンジンの音だ。

examples.en: There was a loud noise from the floor above.
examples.ja: 上のフロアから、大きな音がしました。

examples.en: The sound of the rain was so loud I couldn't rest well.
examples.ja: 雨の音がうるさくて、よく休めませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Did you hear that <vocabulary>sound</vocabulary>? It's barely <reading>audi</reading>ble (おと). Go ahead and say the word "audible" with the pronunciation of おと to help you to remember this.

examples.en: My mother always makes sandwiches.
examples.ja: 母は、いつもサンドイッチを作る。

examples.en: Have you already created a student portal account?
examples.ja: 学生ポータルのアカウントもう作った？

examples.en: I am taking an engineering class because I want to build a robot.
examples.ja: ロボットを作りたくて工学のクラスをとってます。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>make</kanji>. The verb form of that is <vocabulary>to make</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the つく portion. In order to do that let's think about something that you're going to make. Imagine something really awesome. You complete it and look at your masterpiece. It's amazing. You realize right then and there that it's <reading>too coo</reading>l (つく) for the general public to see. You proceed to smash it. It's way too cool.

examples.en: The man has a big body.
examples.ja: その男は体が大きい。

examples.en: Cherish your healthy body for life.
examples.ja: 元気な体を一生大切にしてね。

examples.en: My whole body turned red due to allergies.
examples.ja: アレルギーで体中が赤くなった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You have your body. It's nice - looking good! What would really mess up your body? It would be a <reading>car raider</reading> (からだ). I'm talking about a dude who is a raider of some kind driving a car. If he runs into your body, you're done for, so watch out for the car raider. 

Of course, this mnemonic is only meant to get you close to the reading. Hopefully it is close enough to get you to the actual reading, からだ.

examples.en: Dad doesn't have much endurance.
examples.ja: お父さんは体力がない。

examples.en: I run once a day to improve my stamina.
examples.ja: 体力アップのためにランニングを一日一回してます。

examples.en: My physical strength last year and my current strength are about the same.
examples.ja: 去年の体力と今の体力は、大体同じです。

meaning_mnemonic: You have your <kanji>body</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji>. This is just another way to say <vocabulary>physical strength</vocabulary>. Watch out, if you use too much of your physical strength you may run out of physical <vocabulary>stamina</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>endurance</vocabulary> completely! They're tied together, so make sure to pace yourself.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Your <vocabulary>physical strength</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>stamina</vocabulary> are tied together with a <reading>tie</reading> <reading>lock</reading> (たいりょく). That's a lock made of ties that ties your strength and stamina up together, making it much easier to pace yourself.

examples.en: Water comes out of the body no matter what.
examples.ja: どうしても水は体内から出る。

examples.en: It seems that a virus has entered the body.
examples.ja: 体内にウィルスが入ったようだ。

examples.en: I feel like the alcohol content in the body is lacking.
examples.ja: 体内のアルコール分が不足してる気がします。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>body</kanji>'s <kanji>inside</kanji> means <vocabulary>inside the body</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>internal</vocabulary>.

体内 refers specifically to internal body stuff, so you'll often see it in medical and scientific contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: A seven-year-old boy's essay became a book.
examples.ja: 七才の男の子の作文が本になった。

examples.en: In first grade writing class, we wrote on the theme of "cherry blossom viewing".
examples.ja: 一年生の作文クラスで「お花見」をテーマに作文をした。

examples.en: I corrected composition errors with a fat red pen.
examples.ja: 作文のエラーは太い赤ペンで正しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>make</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji>, what are you doing? Simply put, you're <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary>. If you want to be fancier about it, you could say this is <vocabulary>composition</vocabulary>.

Note that 作文 often refers to the end result of a writing process, like a finished essay, rather than the writing process itself. It’s also commonly associated with various writing tasks assigned to students in Japanese elementary or middle school.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since both 文 and 作 have two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use:

You can't stop writing <vocabulary>composition</vocabulary>s about <reading>sack</reading>s 'n' <reading>bun</reading>s (さくぶん). You're obsessed with them. You've been writing <vocabulary>essay</vocabulary> after essay about sacks 'n' buns. Stop <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary> about sacks 'n' buns!

examples.en: I'm not good at crafts.
examples.ja: わたし、工作が下手なんです。

examples.en: My father built a whole kitchen from a craft kit.
examples.ja: 父は工作キットでキッチンを丸ごとつくった。

examples.en: The teacher crafted an alibi that he was in the bar last evening.
examples.ja: 先生は、夕べはバーにいたというアリバイ工作をしたのだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
What is the "<kanji>industry</kanji> of <kanji>make</kanji>"? Well, it's when you industriously make things, obviously. That can only be <vocabulary>handicraft</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crafts</vocabulary>, often referring to craft activities or hands-on projects done in elementary or middle school!

But wait, 工作 isn't just about glue and popsicle sticks! It can also mean <vocabulary>maneuvering</vocabulary>, in the sense of pulling strings behind the scenes. So, whether you're crafting a masterpiece or scheming a clever plan, 工作 encompasses the wonders of crafting!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Your favorite <vocabulary>handicraft</vocabulary> is making <reading>こう</reading>いち <reading>sack</reading>s (さく). They're sacks that look exactly like こういち, and you're incredibly good at making them. Soon, the Tofugu offices will be decorated all over with your こういち sacks.

examples.en: "Psycho" is Hitchcock's magnum opus.
examples.ja: 「サイコ」はヒッチコックの大作だ。

examples.en: "Star Wars: Episode I" was the most epic American film of 1999.
examples.ja: 「スターウォーズ エピソードI」は１９９９年のアメリカ一の大作でした。

examples.en: I can't come up with any ideas for a masterpiece anymore.
examples.ja: もう自分では大作のアイディアは考えられない。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>make</kanji>! What is your big make? Bigger than anything else. It is your <vocabulary>major work</vocabulary>!

大作 means a large-scale, ambitious, or significant work. Depending on the context, it can refer to anything from an artistically accomplished <vocabulary>masterpiece</vocabulary> to a big-budget <vocabulary>blockbuster</vocabulary> movie.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Did you know that there's a <vocabulary>monumental work</vocabulary> about a <reading>tie</reading> <reading>sack</reading> (たいさく)? It's a <vocabulary>masterpiece</vocabulary> about a magic sack that produces tie after tie after tie after tie... A bit like The Magic Porridge Pot, but with a sack and ties instead.

examples.en: Please look at the diagram below.
examples.ja: 下の図を見てください。

examples.en: I made a diagram to show the lack of population in the village.
examples.ja: 村の人口不足を図にしてみた。

examples.en: The size of diagram can be increased by clicking on it.
examples.ja: 図はクリックすると大きさを上げることができる。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: While words that are made up of a single kanji usually take the kun'yomi reading, this one takes the on'yomi reading. Luckily, this is the same reading you learned with the kanji, so it shouldn't be too hard to remember.

examples.en: Oh, that Dad's voice.
examples.ja: あっ、お父さんの声だ。

examples.en: My voice escaped my mouth unintentionally.
examples.ja: ついつい口から声が出てしまった。

examples.en: Your voice sounds exactly like my friend's.
examples.ja: あなたの声、友人の声とそっくりです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji making it easy to remember!

examples.en: I raised my voice despite myself.
examples.ja: つい大声が出てしまった。

examples.en: I can't say too loudly that I joined the company through a connection.
examples.ja: コネ入社だなんて、大声では言えないよ。

examples.en: When I said "Yahoo" to the mountains, a "Yahoo" echoed back.
examples.ja: 山の方に大声で「やっほー」と言うと「やっほー」と山びこがかえってきた。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is a <vocabulary>loud voice</vocabulary>!

大声 usually just describes talking in a <vocabulary>big voice</vocabulary>, but it can also refer to shouting depending on the situation.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 声 is ごえ (rendaku'd version of the reading you know: こえ). The reading for 大 is the kun'yomi reading, like with the word 大きい (おおきい). Just imagine a loud voice saying "おお！."

examples.en: The boy on the left is my brother.
examples.ja: 左の男の子がわたしの弟です。

examples.en: My brother doesn't watch TV.
examples.ja: 弟は、テレビを見ません。

examples.en: My younger brother and my older brother sound exactly the same.
examples.ja: 弟と兄は声がそっくりです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You look at your younger brother. He's a scheming one. He's smiling up at you. Why? Because he's lit a firecracker on your foot. It explodes, sending your toe flying. You yell <reading>"OH. Toe? TOE!"</reading> (おとうと) as you realize what's going on.

examples.en: Those two are brothers.
examples.ja: あの二人は兄弟です。

examples.en: Were Mario and Luigi brothers!?
examples.ja: マリオとルイージって兄弟だったの！？

examples.en: I have four siblings.
examples.ja: わたしには兄弟が四人います。

meaning_mnemonic: You have an <kanji>older brother</kanji> and a <kanji>younger brother</kanji>. Wow! Both are here. These are <vocabulary>brothers</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The teacher's coming soon.
examples.ja: もうすぐ先生が来る。

examples.en: I come from America.
examples.ja: アメリカから来ました。

examples.en: Mom, please don't come to my office, I beg you.
examples.ja: お母さん、おねがいだから会社には来ないで。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>come</kanji> so you know this word means <vocabulary>to come</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this word is pretty strange. It changes depending on the type of verb form you use (it's a pesky exception verb). To remember the reading of this word, here's a mnemonic: 

"I want you <vocabulary>to come</vocabulary> to the <reading>coo</reading>l (く) side, Luke," says Darth Vader.
"What?" replies Luke.

Just replace this line into the famous line from Star Wars. Say it out loud. Do the Vader voice. It'll help you to remember.

examples.en: Is the piano competition next month?
examples.ja: ピアノのコンクールは来月ですか？

examples.en: We're having a party next month. Please come, Kanae.
examples.ja: 来月、パーティーをするので、かなえさんも来て下さい。

examples.en: The number of new staff members who will join the company next month is about ninety.
examples.ja: 来月入社するスタッフは大体九十人です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>next</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> is the <vocabulary>next month</vocabulary>! It isn't this month or the month before, it's the next one!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

<vocabulary>Next month</vocabulary> is when <reading>rye</reading> <reading>gets</reading> (らいげつ) into your diet! You're going to eat only rye bread and drink only rye beer for all of next month. Bet you can't wait!

examples.en: Next year is the year 2000.
examples.ja: 来年は２０００年です。

examples.en: I will be eighteen next September.
examples.ja: わたしは来年の九月に十八才になります。

examples.en: I'm going to stay in Japan until next year's project.
examples.ja: 来年のプロジェクトまでは日本にいるつもりだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>next</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is <vocabulary>next year</vocabulary>! It isn't last year or this year, it's the next one!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Since ancient times, that mountain has been called "Mt. Fuji."
examples.ja: 古来から、あの山は「ふじ山」という名だ。

examples.en: The kappa is an ancient Japanese yokai.
examples.ja: カッパは、日本古来のヨウカイです。

examples.en: Using bamboo is the ancient way of DIY.
examples.ja: 竹を用いるのは、古来のDIYの仕方です。

meaning_mnemonic:
Things that are really <kanji>old</kanji> <kanji>come</kanji> <vocabulary>from ancient times</vocabulary>!

This is a relatively formal expression that’s used to talk about <vocabulary>age-old</vocabulary> things, like customs that have stood the test of time.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Michael is my father's friend of thirty years.
examples.ja: マイケルは、父の三十年来の友人です。

examples.en: Koichi finally fulfilled his decade-long American dream.
examples.ja: コウイチは、ついに十年来のアメリカンドリームをかなえました。

examples.en: This is a masterpiece fifty years in the making!
examples.ja: これは五十年来の大作ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you have <kanji>year</kanji>s <kanji>com</kanji>ing and going, you know it is <vocabulary>for some years</vocabulary>. Don't confuse this one with 来年 which means "next year." The kanji 来 comes after the kanji for year, so instead of "coming year" it's "years that come (and go)." At least, you can think of it that way to differentiate. 

You can also add numbers to this word. For example ５年来 means something to the tune of "for five years." But this is a pretty formal word. Just keep that in mind.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The company has in-house designers.
examples.ja: 社内にデザイナーがいます。

examples.en: White desks are popular in the company now.
examples.ja: 社内では今、白のデスクが人気です。

examples.en: A message about the company party came as an internal email.
examples.ja: 会社のパーティについてのメッセージが社内メールで回ってきた。

meaning_mnemonic: When you're doing something <kanji>inside</kanji> the <kanji>company</kanji> you're doing it <vocabulary>within the company</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>in-house</vocabulary>. For example, we do our kanji in-house. It gives it that artisan flavor.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I just joined a company.
examples.ja: 入社したばかりです。

examples.en: I joined this company in April.
examples.ja: この会社には、四月に入社しました。

examples.en: What's the date of the company's entrance test?
examples.ja: 入社テストは何日ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>enter</kanji> a <kanji>company</kanji> you're actually <vocabulary>joining a company</vocabulary>. Welcome, new recruit. Prepare to be hazed!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The head office is in Portland.
examples.ja: 本社はポートランドにあります。

examples.en: The HQ has a staff of about 1,000.
examples.ja: 本社にはスタッフが千人ほどいます。

examples.en: It seems like there was unauthorized access to the headquarters' server.
examples.ja: 本社のサーバーに不正アクセスがあったらしい。
