meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>company</kanji> is where everything in your company comes from. This is your main base. This is your <vocabulary>headquarters</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This company has a staff of five hundred.
examples.ja: この会社のスタッフは五百人です。

examples.en: Google is a very big company.
examples.ja: グーグルは、とても大きな会社です。

examples.en: Is there an apartment close to the company?
examples.ja: 会社に近いアパートはありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The place where your <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>s is your <vocabulary>company</vocabulary>. Sony is a company. Nintendo is a company. Etc.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There is a convenience store on the corner.
examples.ja: 角にコンビニがありますよ。

examples.en: A bag was hanging on the corner of the table.
examples.ja: テーブルの角にカバンが下がっていた。

examples.en: Apparently, a shape with five angles is called a "pentagon."
examples.ja: 角が五つあるシェイプのことを、「ペンタゴン」と言うらしい。

meaning_mnemonic:
When the kanji for <kanji>angle</kanji> is used as a standalone word, it usually means <vocabulary>corner</vocabulary>. You can remember this because corners are pretty much the most common kind of angle you see in everyday life.

In math contexts, it can also mean <vocabulary>angle</vocabulary> — just like the kanji's meaning!
reading_mnemonic:
This word has two different meanings and each one has its own reading.

When it's used for <vocabulary>corner</vocabulary>s, the reading is かど. Just picture a deck of <reading>card</reading>s (かど). What's the most important part of the card? The corner! The corners are where the numbers are. Now tape those cards into all the corners of your house. Why? Because it's artsy!

And the second meaning and reading pair is easy — <vocabulary>angle</vocabulary> and かく, which you already know from the kanji!

examples.en: The cheese was triangular.
examples.ja: そのチーズは三角でした。

examples.en: Cut the pineapple into small triangles.
examples.ja: パイナップルは小さく三角に切って下さい。

examples.en: There are two types of tiles, triangular and square.
examples.ja: 三角と四角の二タイプのタイルがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: When you have something with <kanji>three</kanji> <kanji>angle</kanji>s, what shape is that? It's a <vocabulary>triangle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The keys on my keyboard are square.
examples.ja: わたしのキーボードのキーは四角です。

examples.en: Japanese stamps are mainly rectangular.
examples.ja: 日本の切手は主に四角ですよ。

examples.en: Doesn't the character for "kuchi" look like a square?
examples.ja: 「口」と言う字は、ただの四角に見えませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: What shape has <kanji>four</kanji> <kanji>angle</kanji>s? The most common one is a <vocabulary>square</vocabulary>, but it could also be a <vocabulary>rectangle</vocabulary> or even a <vocabulary>cube</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings for the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word!

examples.en: The staff says, "Thank you."
examples.ja: スタッフは「ありがとうございました」と、言う。

examples.en: Please say it a little slower.
examples.ja: もう少しゆっくり言って下さい。

examples.en: Did you tell your teacher "Good morning" today?
examples.ja: 今日はちゃんと先生に「おはようございます」言った？

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>say</kanji>, so the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to say</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

To remember the reading い we use the word "eagle." 

You're trying <vocabulary>to say</vocabulary> something, but every time you try to say anything an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) swoops down and pecks at your face then flies away. Just imagine yourself saying tiny bits of words, then an eagle crashing down on your face. Then, you wait in silence. Nothing happens. You try to say something again, and the eagle swoops down on you again.

examples.en: The water in the valley is clean.
examples.ja: 谷の水はきれいです。

examples.en: There is a girl named Nausicaa in that valley.
examples.ja: あの谷には、ナウシカという名の少女がいますよ。

examples.en: The entrance of the valley is here.
examples.ja: 谷の入り口はここです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji, too, so don't feel like you're stuck in a valley of despair or anything. Rejoice!

examples.en: Wanna run to the restaurant?
examples.ja: レストランまで走る？

examples.en: There is a bus that runs north of town.
examples.ja: 町の北を走るバスがあります。

examples.en: I can't take a life of having to run to the office every day anymore.
examples.ja: 毎日走って会社に行く人生はもうイヤなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>run</kanji> so now you know the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to run</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the はし portion. Think of yourself running. It's nice. As you run, though, you notice the ground changing into something weird and mushy. Everything is turning into <reading>hash</reading> (はし) browns. You start to get sucked in, and soon you can't run anymore. Smell the hash browns and taste them too. What a terrible run this was.

examples.en: Reduce the driving speed.
examples.ja: 走行スピードを下げてください。

examples.en: Do not stand up while the bus is moving.
examples.ja: バスの走行中に立ち上がらないで下さい。

examples.en: Today's driving route is northbound.
examples.ja: 今日の走行ルートは北回りです。

meaning_mnemonic:
A vehicle that <kanji>run</kanji>-<kanji>go</kanji>es is <vocabulary>running</vocabulary> and it's <vocabulary>moving</vocabulary> you somewhere else. You're <vocabulary>traveling</vocabulary>!

This word is typically used to describe the movement of vehicles such as cars and trains. It carries a slightly formal or rigid tone, so keep an eye on our context sentences to make sure you’re using it right!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The convenience store near here is 7-Eleven.
examples.ja: ここから近いコンビニはセブンイレブンです。

examples.en: The population of this village is close to a hundred.
examples.ja: この村の人口は百人に近いです。

examples.en: Is it true that beer is almost like water to American people?
examples.ja: アメリカ人にとって、ビールは水に近いって本当？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>near</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>close</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>nearby</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you.

Who do you want to keep <vocabulary>close</vocabulary> at all times? Your <reading>chica</reading> (ちか), of course. She's your strongest support, so when challenges come your way, you'll want her <vocabulary>nearby</vocabulary>, as close as possible.

examples.en: This restaurant will open soon.
examples.ja: このレストランは近日オープンする。

examples.en: My brother's book will be released in a few days.
examples.ja: 近日、兄の本がリリースされます。

examples.en: I will email you soon.
examples.ja: 近日中にメールしますね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>near</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is a day coming very <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary>. It's a day coming <vocabulary>in a few days</vocabulary> or in the <vocabulary>coming days</vocabulary>. In other words, you wouldn't use this word for something that's going to happen in a few minutes, or a few months.

This is a relatively formal word that is commonly used in professional or official contexts.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

<vocabulary>Soon</vocabulary>, the place where you live will have two <reading>kin</reading>gs. <reading>Gee, two</reading> (きんじつ) of them? Yep, yours is the first country ever to have two kings.

examples.en: In recent years, Japanese whiskey has been trending.
examples.ja: 近年、日本のウィスキーがトレンドです。

examples.en: In recent years, there's been a water shortage in this village.
examples.ja: 近年、この村では水が不足している。

examples.en: In recent years, many first-graders have smartphones.
examples.ja: 近年の一年生は、多くの子がスマホをもっています。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>close</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s are years that aren't too long ago. They are the <vocabulary>recent years</vocabulary>.

This is a formal word that is often used in writing or formal speech.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm allergic to wheat.
examples.ja: 麦アレルギーです。

examples.en: Our hamster seems to like wheat and rice.
examples.ja: うちのハムスターは麦と米を気に入ったみたいです。

examples.en: What's the difference between barley and wheat?
examples.ja: 大麦と小麦のちがいは何ですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji that uses the kun'yomi reading which is the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Paris at night is romantic.
examples.ja: 夜のパリはロマンチックだ。

examples.en: Today's dinner is pasta.
examples.ja: 今日の夜ごはんはパスタです。

examples.en: I often go out at night.
examples.ja: 私は夜に出かけることが多いです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. Fortunately, this is the よる reading you learned with the kanji!

examples.en: A boy was born in 2018.
examples.ja: ２０１８年に男の子が生まれました。

examples.en: Congratulations, mom. It's a cute baby boy!
examples.ja: おめでとうございます、お母さん。かわいい男の子ですよ。

examples.en: That energetic boy will be a first-grader next year.
examples.ja: あの元気な男の子は来年一年生だ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>man</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is a <vocabulary>boy</vocabulary>.

There's a の particle stuck in the middle of this word. Here it just means the noun before の is modifying the noun after. 

But for now, all you really have to remember is that 男の子 means "boy."
reading_mnemonic: If you know the kun'yomi readings of both of these kanji you should be okay. You have two separate single-kanji words put together by a の. That's why it's the kun'yomi reading - they're separate.

examples.en: There was a caterpillar in the cabbage.
examples.ja: キャベツの中に毛虫がいた。

examples.en: It was not soil. It was caterpillar poop.
examples.ja: 土じゃなくて、毛虫のフンだった。

examples.en: This is Charlotte, my pet caterpillar.
examples.ja: ペットの毛虫のシャーロットです。

meaning_mnemonic: When you think of a <kanji>fur</kanji> <kanji>insect</kanji> what do you think of? My mind immediately goes to a <vocabulary>caterpillar</vocabulary>. Imagine the furriest caterpillar you can and touch it. How does it feel? Furry?
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are strange. Both use the kun'yomi readings - 虫 uses the reading you learned with the kanji, so that's easy. The 毛 part is like the vocab word 毛 you learned in the previous lesson.

examples.en: My father was born in a downtown area.
examples.ja: 父は下町で生まれた。

examples.en: I liked the atmosphere and people downtown.
examples.ja: 下町の空気や人々が気に入ったんです。

examples.en: A shitamachi is an old Japanese style of downtown.
examples.ja: 下町とは日本の古いスタイルのダウンタウンのことです。

meaning_mnemonic: You have the <kanji>below</kanji> <kanji>town</kanji>. Does this sort of sound familiar? We have another word for it in English, but it's essentially the same thing: <vocabulary>downtown</vocabulary>. It isn't the downtown you might be used to though. In Japan, this is an old word that was used for the commercial districts literally, physically down (lower than) the main city. So picture an old, urban Japanese area!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is all kun'yomi despite being jukugo. Just think of sketchy things going on in the downtown, just like how there's sketchy kun'yomi readings for this word. You should know both the kun'yomi readings from the previous level, though, so if you do you know the reading for this word as well.

examples.en: Tanaka sensei is a man.
examples.ja: 田中先生は男の人です。

examples.en: There were not many boots for men.
examples.ja: 男の人用のブーツは中々ありませんでした。

examples.en: A romantic man tends to do a flash mob when proposing.
examples.ja: ロマンチックな男の人ってプロポーズでフラッシュモブやりがちよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>man</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>man</vocabulary>. 

There's a の particle stuck in the middle of this word. Here it just means the noun before の is modifying the noun after. 

Don't worry if that's hard to remember though. Just remember 男の人 means "man" (and that it's more polite than plain 男).
reading_mnemonic: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 4 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

examples.en: Thanks for everything so far.
examples.ja: 今まで、ありがとう。

examples.en: What have you been up to so far?
examples.ja: 今まで何をしていたんですか。

examples.en: What Koichi has been saying until now was true.
examples.ja: 今までコウイチが言ってたことは本当だった。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 今 means now. What you probably don't know is that まで means "until." So, this word means <vocabulary>until now</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading which you learned previously when you learned the vocab word 今. You can tell this is a kun'yomi reading because it has hiragana attached. So if you know that, you should be able to read this word as well.

examples.en: Please give me some pink wool.
examples.ja: ピンク色の毛糸を下さい。

examples.en: Grandma gave me a wool blanket she made herself.
examples.ja: おばあちゃんが自分で作った毛糸のブランケットをくれました。

examples.en: These jeans are actually made of wool.
examples.ja: このジーンズ、本当は毛糸でできています。

meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>fur</kanji> <kanji>string</kanji> (aka string made of fur) what do you think of? Hopefully <vocabulary>wool yarn</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. With 毛 you should have learned this reading via the vocab word in the previous level. With 糸 it's actually the main reading for the kanji, so you should already know it.

examples.en: I'm going to the supermarket right now.
examples.ja: 今すぐスーパーにいってきます。

examples.en: Watch the news on TV right now!
examples.ja: 今すぐテレビのニュース見て！

examples.en: I'm going to come pick you up on a private jet right now.
examples.ja: 今すぐプライベートジェットで、むかえに行くよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You'll have to learn this word in two parts. You already know the meaning of 今 because of the kanji, which means "now." The すぐ part, however, is a new word, meaning "soon." すぐ and "soon" even start with a similar sound, so maybe that can help you remember this! If you put 今 and すぐ together, you get "now soon." Put in better English, that's <vocabulary>at once</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>right now</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since you already know the vocab word 今 (read いま), you should be able to read this word as well.

examples.en: That mountain is this bear's hometown.
examples.ja: あの山は、このクマの里なんです。

examples.en: I left my hometown at the age of sixteen and became a web designer.
examples.ja: 十六才で里から出て、ウェブデザイナーになりました。

examples.en: I went down to the village to get some water.
examples.ja: 水を手に入れるため、里に下りた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is the village you came from. This is where your parents live. This is your <vocabulary>hometown</vocabulary> (same meaning as the kanji you learned).

This word is old-fashioned and evokes a warm, nostalgic image of home. Often seen in folktales and traditional songs, it represents an idyllic, pastoral life.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as with the kanji you learned, so you should feel nice and "at home" with this one 😉

examples.en: I’m a bit homesick.
examples.ja: ちょっと里心がついちゃったんです。

examples.en: The nostalgic melody made me homesick.
examples.ja: なつかしいメロディーに、里心がわいた。

examples.en: This puppy may be crying because he is homesick, but who cares?
examples.ja: この仔犬は里心がついて泣いているのかもしれないけど、そんなのかまうもんか。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have your <kanji>home village</kanji> and your <kanji>heart</kanji>. Your heart always resides in your home village, so when you leave you feel <vocabulary>homesick</vocabulary>.

Young people don't really use this word anymore. It's more for the oldies. If you're an oldie, go right ahead. If you're a youngie, then talk to more oldies!
reading_mnemonic: The readings are double kun'yomi. The kun'yomi reading is what you learned with 里 already, though you'll have to pull out the 心 vocab reading to remember it all. Not only that, the 心 gets rendaku'd here making it ごころ. Make sure you watch out for that.

examples.en: Is that true?
examples.ja: それは本当ですか？

examples.en: I wonder if they will give you a million yen from this campaign?
examples.ja: キャンペーンで百万円くれるって、本当かな？

examples.en: I'm really bad at handwriting.
examples.ja: 本当に字が下手なのです。

meaning_mnemonic: What is <kanji>real</kanji> is <kanji>right</kanji>. It is the <vocabulary>reality</vocabulary>. It is also the <vocabulary>truth</vocabulary>. Don't believe anything that isn't <vocabulary>real</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>true</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There's a pig over there.
examples.ja: あそこに豚がいるよ。

examples.en: Wow, it's a piglet! Cute.
examples.ja: わっ、子豚だ！かわいい。

examples.en: This is the first time I have seen a pig in real life.
examples.ja: ホンモノの豚を見るのは、これがはじめてです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I wonder if that paid parking has an available spot.
examples.ja: あのコインパーキング、空車あるかな？

examples.en: There are no available Ubers or Lyfts today.
examples.ja: 今日はUberもLyftも中々空車がいない。

examples.en: In New York, if you see an available taxi raise your hand and shout, "Taxi!"
examples.ja: ニューヨークでは、空車のタクシーを見たら手を上げて大声で「タクシー！」と言って下さい。

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned 空 means "sky," but it can also mean "empty." An <kanji>empty</kanji> <kanji>car</kanji> literally means "empty car," but in practice, you'll usually see this lit up on a taxi to mean <vocabulary>open taxi</vocabulary>. If you spot it, feel free to hail it down!

You might also see 空車 at a parking lot. In that case, it means there's an <vocabulary>empty parking space</vocabulary> available.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is archaeological research.
examples.ja: これは考古学のリサーチです。

examples.en: The data is correct from an archeological point of view.
examples.ja: 考古学の見方では正しいデータです。

examples.en: I'm having a hard time deciding whether I should go with engineering or archeology.
examples.ja: 工学と考古学、どちらにするか、まよっています。

meaning_mnemonic: If you often <kanji>think</kanji> about <kanji>study</kanji>ing <kanji>old</kanji> things, it's called <vocabulary>archeology</vocabulary>. All archeology involves thinking about old things, at least a little bit.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My husband is my partner for life.
examples.ja: 主人は一生のパートナーです。

examples.en: If you don't do various things yourself, you'll go your whole life without being independent.
examples.ja: 色々自分でやらないと、一生自立できないよ。

examples.en: Do you intend to be a freshman in college your whole life?
examples.ja: あなたは一生、大学一年生でいるつもりですか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji> is all you get. It's your <vocabulary>whole life</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>all through life</vocabulary>, and when it's used as an adjective it means <vocabulary>lifelong</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 生 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who has been in charge of you your <vocabulary>whole life</vocabulary>? The <reading>sho</reading>gun (しょう). He owns everyone and that's how it will stay for your <vocabulary>entire life</vocabulary>.

examples.en: That child's gesture is just like an adult's.
examples.ja: あの子の仕草は、まるで大人の仕草だ。

examples.en: The way you cut trees looks exactly like how your dad does it.
examples.ja: 木を切る仕草がお父さんにそっくりです。

examples.en: The teacher's gestures are feminine.
examples.ja: 先生の仕草は女の人らしい。

meaning_mnemonic: Things you end up <kanji>doing</kanji> in the <kanji>grass</kanji> and not inside probably take a lot of big <vocabulary>gesture</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>action</vocabulary>s. You have to do them outside on the grass because if you did them anywhere else you might break something.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this. Just watch out because rendaku makes くさ become ぐさ.

examples.en: The te-form of "deru" is "dete."
examples.ja: 「出る」の「て形」は「出て」です。

examples.en: In the company, we communicate using the desu/masu form.
examples.ja: 会社では、です・ます形を用いてコミュニケーションをとります。

examples.en: "You were an important person?" Why did you say it in the past tense?
examples.ja: 「大切な人だった」？どうして今、カコ形で言ったの？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word share one of the same meanings: <vocabulary>form</vocabulary>. It doesn't just mean form though, it means <vocabulary>tense</vocabulary> too. Like verb tense.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: There are many books about Japanese diplomacy.
examples.ja: 日本の外交についての本はたくさんある。

examples.en: Diplomatic skills are not enough.
examples.ja: 外交力が足りないんですよ。

examples.en: Who leads diplomacy with the United States?
examples.ja: アメリカとの外交をリードする人はだれですか？

meaning_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>mix</kanji> opinions from <kanji>outside</kanji> your country into the way you handle things. That's called <vocabulary>diplomacy</vocabulary>. If you mix your country with the ones outside of your own, you'll all profit!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m Japanese, but I was born in San Francisco.
examples.ja: わたしは日本人ですが、生まれはサンフランシスコです。

examples.en: My former partner is American-born Japanese.
examples.ja: 元パートナーは、アメリカ生まれの日本人なんです。

examples.en: I was born in France.
examples.ja: フランス生まれです。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 生まれる means "to be born?" Well once you're born that place where it happened becomes your <vocabulary>birthplace</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 生まれる. Just drop the る off the end and you have your reading!

examples.en: It's mostly correct.
examples.ja: 大体は正しいです。

examples.en: Right and left hands are about the same size.
examples.ja: 右手と左手の大きさは大体同じです。

examples.en: It takes about three days.
examples.ja: 大体三日かかります。

meaning_mnemonic: If all you can see is the <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> of something, then you'll only get a <vocabulary>general</vocabulary> idea of what it is. You'll be able to say that it's <vocabulary>generally</vocabulary> a certain way, but that's <vocabulary>about</vocabulary> all. You'll get the <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary>, but no more.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

<vocabulary>Generally</vocabulary>, it's a bad idea to <reading>dye</reading> your <reading>tie</reading>s (だいたい). The tie police isn't a big fan of it, and you wouldn't wanna get arrested!

examples.en: I'm starting a literature course in April.
examples.ja: 四月から文学のコースに入ります。

examples.en: I studied British literature and French literature.
examples.ja: イギリス文学とフランス文学を学びました。

examples.en: This book is one of the greatest works of Japanese literature ever written.
examples.ja: この本は、今までの日本文学の中でも大作です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji>, it's called <vocabulary>literature</vocabulary>. You'll get to study lots of things other people wrote before you!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 文 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

All the great works of <vocabulary>literature</vocabulary> are about <reading>bun</reading>s (ぶん). That's the subtle thread running through all literature: buns.

examples.en: This is the original name of the village.
examples.ja: これが、本来の村の名です。

examples.en: Primarily it is an Italian restaurant, but they also have ramen.
examples.ja: 本来はイタリアンレストランですが、ラーメンもあります。

examples.en: I usually work remote, but today I am at the head office.
examples.ja: 本来はリモートワークですが、今日は本社にいます。

meaning_mnemonic: You want to talk about the <kanji>origin</kanji> where something <kanji>come</kanji>s from. That's where it is from <vocabulary>originally</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This bread is 200 yen per loaf.
examples.ja: このパンは一斤当たり二百円です。

examples.en: I'll give you an extra loaf of this bread for free.
examples.ja: このパン、一斤サービスするよ。

examples.en: I ate four loaves of bread in one sitting from stress.
examples.ja: ストレスで四斤のパンを一気にたべてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: This has the 〜 for counters, so you can bet this shares the <vocabulary>bread loaf counter</vocabulary> meaning with the kanji.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Recycle the other kinds of trash.
examples.ja: その他のゴミはリサイクルして下さい。

examples.en: There are many other types than this.
examples.ja: その他色々なタイプありますよ。

examples.en: Is there anything else you would like to say to your ex?
examples.ja: その他に元パートナーへ言いたいことはありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: その means "that" or "the", and その plus <kanji>other</kanji> means things like <vocabulary>the others</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>other</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>other than that</vocabulary>, depending on the context.
reading_mnemonic: This has two readings, but luckily you learned one of them when you learned the kanji, and the other one when you learned the word 他. The two readings are usually interchangeable, too.

examples.en: The elevator is located at the west exit.
examples.ja: エレベーターは西口にあります。

examples.en: I'll be at the cafe at the west exit!
examples.ja: 西口のカフェにいますね！

examples.en: I always take a cab from the west exit.
examples.ja: いつも西口からタクシーにのります。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 北口 from a couple levels ago, and how 入り口 means "entrance" and 出口 means "exit?" Combine that 口 meaning with the kanji for <kanji>west</kanji>, and you get <vocabulary>west exit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>west entrance</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This follows the same pattern as 入り口, 出口, and 北口, so it uses kun'yomi readings. And just like with those, make sure to watch out for the rendaku that changes くち to ぐち!

examples.en: There's a crescent moon today.
examples.ja: 今日は三日月です。

examples.en: You have eyes that are like a crescent moon.
examples.ja: 三日月のような目をしてますね。

examples.en: You can see the crescent moon well from the top of the mountain.
examples.ja: 山の上から三日月がよく見える。

meaning_mnemonic: What's a "third day moon"? It's a <vocabulary>crescent moon</vocabulary>. A crescent moon is the newly visible moon that appears on the third day of the month in the lunar calendar that Japanese people used back in the day.
reading_mnemonic:
The word comes from 三日 and 月, but the readings are slightly different. There's no small つ in the reading for 三日, and you need to rendaku 月, all to make it easier to pronounce. Try reading it aloud yourself to see what I mean!
To write the character づ, type "du" on your keyboard.

examples.en: That looks fun!
examples.ja: それ、おもしろそうだね！

examples.en: Oh, you're going to go for that?
examples.ja: え、それにするの？

examples.en: That's not candy, that's an eyeball.
examples.ja: それはキャンディじゃなくて目玉です。

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Sorry</reading> (それ), can you grab <vocabulary>that one</vocabulary> for me? Yeah, <vocabulary>that</vocabulary>, thanks!

You can use それ for things that are close to the person you're talking to, or fairly close to both of you.

examples.en: Oh, you work part-time at a convenience store?
examples.ja: え、コンビニでバイトしてるの？

examples.en: Convenience store rice balls are so good!
examples.ja: コンビニのおにぎりっておいしいよね！

examples.en: Oh, there's a convenience store over there!
examples.ja: あ、あそこにコンビニがある！

meaning_mnemonic:
コンビニ comes from the English word <vocabulary>convenience store</vocabulary>, but who has time for all those syllables? That's why they cut it down to "conveni". So much more convenient that way.

Watch out for the “v” sound, which usually becomes “b” in Japanese, and this word is no exception.

examples.en: I'm in the department store restroom right now.
examples.ja: 今、デパートのトイレにいる。

examples.en: They had that at the department store.
examples.ja: それ、デパートにあったよ。

examples.en: I saw Leo at the department store!
examples.ja: レオなら、デパートで見かけたよ！

meaning_mnemonic: デパート comes from  <vocabulary>department store</vocabulary>. Yet another shortened loanword! There's an extra "o" sound on the end of this one, since a word can't end in "t" in Japanese.

examples.en: Oh, excuse me! I'm sorry!
examples.ja: あ、すみません！ごめんなさい！

examples.en: Excuse me, where's the "Ocean Hotel"?
examples.ja: すみません、オーシャンホテルってどこですか。

examples.en: Excuse me, is now a good time?
examples.ja: すみません、今ちょっといいですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Sue me, Ma Sen!</reading> (すみません), you yell at Ma Sen, before quickly adding "<vocabulary>Excuse me</vocabulary>…<vocabulary>I'm sorry</vocabulary>, so <vocabulary> sorry</vocabulary>!" You shouldn't have shouted at Ma Sen like that. You hope she won’t actually sue you.

You can use すみません both to apologize and to get someone’s attention. This expression is really common in Japan, and dropping it in wherever you can will help you blend right in!

examples.en: No, it's not.
examples.ja: いいえ、ちがいます。

examples.en: No, you have the wrong person.
examples.ja: いいえ、人ちがいです。

examples.en: No, it's not England. It's Canada.
examples.ja: いいえ、イギリスじゃないです。カナダです。

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Eeh! Eh?</reading> (いいえ) <vocabulary>No</vocabulary>! You’re so surprised by whatever the question was, you can only manage "Eeh! Eh? No!" in response.

いいえ is a formal word for "no", so you can use it to answer politely in the negative.

examples.en: Is this your blog?
examples.ja: これ、あなたのブログですか？

examples.en: What would you do in that kind of situation?
examples.ja: こんなとき、あなたならどうしますか？

examples.en: I miss you darling.
examples.ja: あなたがいなくてさみしいです。

meaning_mnemonic:
"<reading>A gnat, ah!</reading> (あなた). I’m going to get <vocabulary>you</vocabulary>! Yes YOU," you shout as you swat at that pesky gnat buzzing around your head.

あなた is a lot less common than “you” in English, but you’ll come across it in adverts, online forums, and textbooks, where it’s used to address a general, anonymous audience. Some people also use it with their significant other, in which case it sounds intimate, like "darling". In casual conversations, though, it can come off as standoffish, so it's better to use someone's name or social title (like "teacher") instead.

examples.en: Dad is good at tennis.
examples.ja: パパはテニスが上手い。

examples.en: A skillful person joined the team.
examples.ja: 上手い人がチームに入った。

examples.en: This composition is pretty well-written.
examples.ja: この作文、なかなか上手いですね。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 上手 means that you're <vocabulary>good at</vocabulary> something? Well, this word uses the exact same kanji, and means the exact same thing!
reading_mnemonic:
That い on the end is your clue that the reading is different, and you can forget about the readings you learned for each kanji. This is a native Japanese word, and the kanji were assigned to it based on the meaning alone. That means you just have to memorize the reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you see that someone's <vocabulary>good at</vocabulary> something, you say, "<reading>Ooh</reading>, <reading>my</reading> (うまい)!" at the top of your lungs. Try it! Think of something that impresses you and say "ooh my!" out loud.

examples.en: The man over there is in his thirties.
examples.ja: あの男は三十代です。

examples.en: I joined this company in my thirties.
examples.ja: 三十代で、この会社に入りました。

examples.en: My parents were in their thirties when they had their three children.
examples.ja: 三人の子どもが生まれたとき、父と母は三十代でした。

meaning_mnemonic: You have the number "thirty", and <kanji>age</kanji>. So this refers to <vocabulary>one's thirties</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This uses on'yomi for all the kanji, so you should be good to go here!

examples.en: I would like to pay for the books by card.
examples.ja: 本の代金はカードではらいます。

examples.en: The massage costs 50 dollars.
examples.ja: マッサージ代金は五十ドルです。

examples.en: We haven't received payment for today's lunch yet.
examples.ja: まだ今日のランチの代金をもらってません。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you buy something, you basically <kanji>substitute</kanji> it with <kanji>money</kanji>. That substitute money is the <vocabulary>cost</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>price</vocabulary> of the thing you're paying for.

There are a lot of money-related synonyms in Japanese, but keep in mind this one refers to the money you pay to get some stuff in return (usually goods), not to an expense, price, or value. It's "substitute money" after all!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which means it uses on'yomi readings for both of the kanji. You already know those, so you should be good to go!
